API ReferenceÂ¶

ConnectionsÂ¶

The connect function is the primary entry point for the SingleStore package. It connects to a SingleStore database using either DB-API compliant parameters, or a connection string in the form of a URL.

connect([host,Â user,Â password,Â port,Â ...])

Return a SingleStore database connection.

ConnectionÂ¶

Connection objects are created by the connect() function. They are used to create Cursor objects for querying the database.

Connection(**kwargs)

SingleStore database connection.

Connection.autocommit([value])

Set autocommit mode.

Connection.close()

Close the database connection.

Connection.commit()

Commit the pending transaction.

Connection.rollback()

Rollback the pending transaction.

Connection.cursor()

Create a new cursor object.

Connection.is_connected()

Determine if the database is still connected.

Connection.enable_http_api([port])

Enable the HTTP API in the server.

Connection.disable_http_api()

Disable the HTTP API.

CursorÂ¶

Cursors are used to query the database and download results. They are created using the Connection.cursor() method.

Cursor(connection,Â cursor,Â driver)

Database cursor for submitting commands and queries.

Cursor.callproc(name[,Â params])

Call a stored procedure.

Cursor.close()

Close the cursor.

Cursor.execute(oper[,Â params])

Execute a SQL statement.

Cursor.executemany(oper[,Â param_seq])

Execute SQL code against multiple sets of parameters.

Cursor.fetchone()

Fetch a single row from the result set.

Cursor.fetchmany([size])

Fetch size rows from the result.

Cursor.fetchall()

Fetch all rows in the result set.

Cursor.nextset()

Skip to the next available result set.

Cursor.setinputsizes(sizes)

Predefine memory areas for parameters.

Cursor.setoutputsize(size[,Â column])

Set a column buffer size for fetches of large columns.

Cursor.scroll(value[,Â mode])

Scroll the cursor to the position in the result set.

Cursor.next()

Return the next row from the result set for use in iterators.

Cursor.is_connected()

Check if the cursor is connected.

Cluster ManagementÂ¶

The cluster management objects allow you to create, destroy, and interact with clusters in the SingleStore managed service.

manage_cluster([access_token,Â version,Â base_url])

Retrieve a SingleStore cluster manager.

ClusterManagerÂ¶

ClusterManager objects are returned by the manage_cluster() function. They allow you to retrieve information about clusters in your account, or create new ones.

ClusterManager([access_token,Â version,Â base_url])

SingleStore cluster manager.

ClusterManager.clusters

Return a list of available clusters.

ClusterManager.regions

Return a list of available regions.

ClusterManager.create_cluster(name,Â ...[,Â ...])

Create a new cluster.

ClusterManager.get_cluster(cluster_id)

Retrieve a cluster definition.

ClusterÂ¶

Cluster objects are retrieved from ClusterManager.get_cluster() or by retrieving an element from CluterManager.clusters.

Cluster(name,Â cluster_id,Â region,Â size,Â ...)

SingleStore cluster definition.

Cluster.refresh()

Update the object to the current state.

Cluster.update([name,Â admin_password,Â ...])

Update the cluster definition.

Cluster.suspend([wait_on_suspended,Â ...])

Suspend the cluster.

Cluster.resume([wait_on_resumed,Â ...])

Resume the cluster.

Cluster.terminate([wait_on_terminated,Â ...])

Terminate the cluster.

Cluster.connect(**kwargs)

Create a connection to the database server for this cluster.

RegionÂ¶

Region objects are accessed from the ClusterManager.regions attribute.

Region(region_id,Â region,Â provider)

Cluster region information.

ConfigurationÂ¶

The following functions are used to get and set package configuration settings. Execute the singlestore.describe_option() function with no parameters to see the documentation for all options.

get_option(key)

Get the value of an option.

set_option(*args,Â **kwargs)

Set the value of an option.

describe_option(*keys,Â **kwargs)

Print the description of one or more options.

In addition to the function above, you can access options through the singlestore.options object. This gives you attribute-like access to the option values.

In [1]: import singlestore as s2

In [2]: s2.describe_option('results.format')
results.format : string
    What form should the query results take?
    [default: tuple] [currently: tuple]



In [3]: s2.options.results.format
Out[3]: 'tuple'

In [4]: s2.options.results.format = 'namedtuple'

In [5]: s2.describe_option('results.format')
results.format : string
    What form should the query results take?
    [default: tuple] [currently: namedtuple]
